creator: beland@alum.mit.edu
text:
When I choose "Help" from the "Help" menu, in the window that appears I see raw
HTML starting with "<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC " and then some HTML comments
containing the license, content stylesheet, etc.  The text is not easily
cut-and-pasted, so I have not copied the whole thing here.

I was expecting to see rendered content explaining how to use the application.

This is on Fedora 6 with the jdk-1.6.0-fcs RPM.

Works for me with jre 1.6.0_01-b06 from Sun.

It does not work in the default JVM gij 4.1.1 - are you sure that you are not 
using that by mistake?

Check jmeter.log for errors.
creator: sebb@apache.org

text:
Ah, /usr/bin/java was actually pointing to a binary in the
java-1.4.2-gcj-compat-1.4.2.0-40jpp.110 RPM, which is required via dependency
chain from OpenOffice.  I changed java and javac to point to binaries from the
jdk-1.6.0_01-fcs RPM, and now I see rendered HTML when engaging the help system.

Section 2.1.1 "Java Version" of
http://jakarta.apache.org/jmeter/usermanual/get-started.html says "Use the
latest version of Java 1.4 or 1.5 for best results".  It should probably not be
recommending 1.4 if that's known not to work.
creator: beland@alum.mit.edu
sebb@apache.org
text: As far as I know it does work with Sun Java 1.4 on Linux.

Between this bug and 42427, I would say JMeter doesn't work on the version of
Java 1.4.2 included with Fedora 6.
creator: beland@alum.mit.edu
sebb@apache.org
text:
That may be, but as far as I can tell that is a problem with the JVM, not 
JMeter.

It doesn't really matter where the problem is, as far as the documentation is
concerned. The question for the reader is what versions of Java the current
JMeter distribution will run on.
creator: beland@alum.mit.edu

text: Re-opening, since documentation is still recommending java 1.3, 1.4, or 1.5.
creator: beland@alum.mit.edu
sebb@apache.org
text:
As far as I am aware, the documentation now only recommends a fully compliant 
Java 1.4 or later.

Please re-open with full details if this is not the case.
